text: At the Bay
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: I
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: Very early morning. The sun was not yet risen, and the whole of
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: Crescent Bay was hidden under a white sea-mist. The big bush-covered
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: hills at the back were smothered. You could not see where they ended
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: and the paddocks and bungalows began. The sandy road was gone and the
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: paddocks and bungalows the other side of it; there were no white dunes
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: covered with reddish grass beyond them; there was nothing to mark which
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: was beach and where was the sea. A heavy dew had fallen. The grass was
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: blue. Big drops hung on the bushes and just did not fall; the silvery,
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: fluffy toi-toi was limp on its long stalks, and all the marigolds and
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: the pinks in the bungalow gardens were bowed to the earth with wetness.
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: Drenched were the cold fuchsias, round pearls of dew lay on the flat
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: nasturtium leaves. It looked as though the sea had beaten up softly in
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: the darkness, as though one immense wave had come rippling,
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: rippling—how far? Perhaps if you had waked up in the middle of the
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: night you might have seen a big fish flicking in at the window and gone
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: again....
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: Ah-Aah! sounded the sleepy sea. And from the bush there came the sound
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: of little streams flowing, quickly, lightly, slipping between the
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: smooth stones, gushing into ferny basins and out again; and there was
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: the splashing of big drops on large leaves, and something else—what was
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: it?—a faint stirring and shaking, the snapping of a twig and then such
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: silence that it seemed some one was listening.
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: Round the corner of Crescent Bay, between the piled-up masses of broken
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: rock, a flock of sheep came pattering. They were huddled together, a
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: small, tossing, woolly mass, and their thin, stick-like legs trotted
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: along quickly as if the cold and the quiet had frightened them. Behind
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: them an old sheep-dog, his soaking paws covered with sand, ran along
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: with his nose to the ground, but carelessly, as if thinking of
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: something else. And then in the rocky gateway the shepherd himself
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: appeared. He was a lean, upright old man, in a frieze coat that was
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: covered with a web of tiny drops, velvet trousers tied under the knee,
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: and a wide-awake with a folded blue handkerchief round the brim. One
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: hand was crammed into his belt, the other grasped a beautifully smooth
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: yellow stick. And as he walked, taking his time, he kept up a very soft
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: light whistling, an airy, far-away fluting that sounded mournful and
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: tender. The old dog cut an ancient caper or two and then drew up sharp,
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: ashamed of his levity, and walked a few dignified paces by his master’s
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: side. The sheep ran forward in little pattering rushes; they began to
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: bleat, and ghostly flocks and herds answered them from under the sea.
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: “Baa! Baaa!” For a time they seemed to be always on the same piece of
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: ground. There ahead was stretched the sandy road with shallow puddles;
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: the same soaking bushes showed on either side and the same shadowy
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: palings. Then something immense came into view; an enormous
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: shock-haired giant with his arms stretched out. It was the big gum-tree
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: outside Mrs. Stubbs’ shop, and as they passed by there was a strong
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: whiff of eucalyptus. And now big spots of light gleamed in the mist.
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: The shepherd stopped whistling; he rubbed his red nose and wet beard on
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: his wet sleeve and, screwing up his eyes, glanced in the direction of
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: the sea. The sun was rising. It was marvellous how quickly the mist
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: thinned, sped away, dissolved from the shallow plain, rolled up from
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: the bush and was gone as if in a hurry to escape; big twists and curls
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: jostled and shouldered each other as the silvery beams broadened. The
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: far-away sky—a bright, pure blue—was reflected in the puddles, and the
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: drops, swimming along the telegraph poles, flashed into points of
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: light. Now the leaping, glittering sea was so bright it made one’s eyes
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: ache to look at it. The shepherd drew a pipe, the bowl as small as an
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: acorn, out of his breast pocket, fumbled for a chunk of speckled
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: tobacco, pared off a few shavings and stuffed the bowl. He was a grave,
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: fine-looking old man. As he lit up and the blue smoke wreathed his
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: head, the dog, watching, looked proud of him.
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: “Baa! Baaa!” The sheep spread out into a fan. They were just clear of
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: the summer colony before the first sleeper turned over and lifted a
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: drowsy head; their cry sounded in the dreams of little children... who
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: lifted their arms to drag down, to cuddle the darling little woolly
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: lambs of sleep. Then the first inhabitant appeared; it was the
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: Burnells’ cat Florrie, sitting on the gatepost, far too early as usual,
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: looking for their milk-girl. When she saw the old sheep-dog she sprang
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: up quickly, arched her back, drew in her tabby head, and seemed to give
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: a little fastidious shiver. “Ugh! What a coarse, revolting creature!”
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: said Florrie. But the old sheep-dog, not looking up, waggled past,
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: flinging out his legs from side to side. Only one of his ears twitched
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: to prove that he saw, and thought her a silly young female.
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: The breeze of morning lifted in the bush and the smell of leaves and
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: wet black earth mingled with the sharp smell of the sea. Myriads of
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: birds were singing. A goldfinch flew over the shepherd’s head and,
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: perching on the tiptop of a spray, it turned to the sun, ruffling its
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: small breast feathers. And now they had passed the fisherman’s hut,
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: passed the charred-looking little _whare_ where Leila the milk-girl
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: lived with her old Gran. The sheep strayed over a yellow swamp and Wag,
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: the sheep-dog, padded after, rounded them up and headed them for the
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: steeper, narrower rocky pass that led out of Crescent Bay and towards
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: Daylight Cove. “Baa! Baa!” Faint the cry came as they rocked along the
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: fast-drying road. The shepherd put away his pipe, dropping it into his
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: breast-pocket so that the little bowl hung over. And straightway the
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: soft airy whistling began again. Wag ran out along a ledge of rock
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: after something that smelled, and ran back again disgusted. Then
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: pushing, nudging, hurrying, the sheep rounded the bend and the shepherd
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: followed after out of sight.
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: II
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: A few moments later the back door of one of the bungalows opened, and a
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: figure in a broad-striped bathing suit flung down the paddock, cleared
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: the stile, rushed through the tussock grass into the hollow, staggered
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: up the sandy hillock, and raced for dear life over the big porous
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: stones, over the cold, wet pebbles, on to the hard sand that gleamed
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: like oil. Splish-Splosh! Splish-Splosh! The water bubbled round his
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: legs as Stanley Burnell waded out exulting. First man in as usual! He’d
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: beaten them all again. And he swooped down to souse his head and neck.
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: “Hail, brother! All hail, Thou Mighty One!” A velvety bass voice came
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: booming over the water.
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: Great Scott! Damnation take it! Stanley lifted up to see a dark head
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: bobbing far out and an arm lifted. It was Jonathan Trout—there before
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: him! “Glorious morning!” sang the voice.
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: “Yes, very fine!” said Stanley briefly. Why the dickens didn’t the
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: fellow stick to his part of the sea? Why should he come barging over to
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: this exact spot? Stanley gave a kick, a lunge and struck out, swimming
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: overarm. But Jonathan was a match for him. Up he came, his black hair
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: sleek on his forehead, his short beard sleek.
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: “I had an extraordinary dream last night!” he shouted.
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: What was the matter with the man? This mania for conversation irritated
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: Stanley beyond words. And it was always the same—always some piffle
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: about a dream he’d had, or some cranky idea he’d got hold of, or some
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: rot he’d been reading. Stanley turned over on his back and kicked with
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: his legs till he was a living waterspout. But even then.... “I dreamed
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: I was hanging over a terrifically high cliff, shouting to some one
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: below.” You would be! thought Stanley. He could stick no more of it. He
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: stopped splashing. “Look here, Trout,” he said, “I’m in rather a hurry
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: this morning.”
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: “You’re WHAT?” Jonathan was so surprised—or pretended to be—that he
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: sank under the water, then reappeared again blowing.
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: “All I mean is,” said Stanley, “I’ve no time to—to—to fool about. I
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: want to get this over. I’m in a hurry. I’ve work to do this
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: morning—see?”
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: Jonathan was gone before Stanley had finished. “Pass, friend!” said the
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: bass voice gently, and he slid away through the water with scarcely a
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: ripple.... But curse the fellow! He’d ruined Stanley’s bathe. What an
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: unpractical idiot the man was! Stanley struck out to sea again, and
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: then as quickly swam in again, and away he rushed up the beach. He felt
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: cheated.
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: Jonathan stayed a little longer in the water. He floated, gently moving
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: his hands like fins, and letting the sea rock his long, skinny body. It
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: was curious, but in spite of everything he was fond of Stanley Burnell.
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: True, he had a fiendish desire to tease him sometimes, to poke fun at
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: him, but at bottom he was sorry for the fellow. There was something
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: pathetic in his determination to make a job of everything. You couldn’t
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: help feeling he’d be caught out one day, and then what an almighty
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: cropper he’d come! At that moment an immense wave lifted Jonathan, rode
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: past him, and broke along the beach with a joyful sound. What a beauty!
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: And now there came another. That was the way to live—carelessly,
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: recklessly, spending oneself. He got on to his feet and began to wade
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: towards the shore, pressing his toes into the firm, wrinkled sand. To
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: take things easy, not to fight against the ebb and flow of life, but to
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: give way to it—that was what was needed. It was this tension that was
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: all wrong. To live—to live! And the perfect morning, so fresh and fair,
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: basking in the light, as though laughing at its own beauty, seemed to
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: whisper, “Why not?”
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: But now he was out of the water Jonathan turned blue with cold. He
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: ached all over; it was as though some one was wringing the blood out of
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: him. And stalking up the beach, shivering, all his muscles tight, he
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: too felt his bathe was spoilt. He’d stayed in too long.
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: III
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: Beryl was alone in the living-room when Stanley appeared, wearing a
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: blue serge suit, a stiff collar and a spotted tie. He looked almost
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: uncannily clean and brushed; he was going to town for the day. Dropping
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: into his chair, he pulled out his watch and put it beside his plate.
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: “I’ve just got twenty-five minutes,” he said. “You might go and see if
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: the porridge is ready, Beryl?”
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: “Mother’s just gone for it,” said Beryl. She sat down at the table and
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: poured out his tea.
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: “Thanks!” Stanley took a sip. “Hallo!” he said in an astonished voice,
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: “you’ve forgotten the sugar.”
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: “Oh, sorry!” But even then Beryl didn’t help him; she pushed the basin
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: across. What did this mean? As Stanley helped himself his blue eyes
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: widened; they seemed to quiver. He shot a quick glance at his
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: sister-in-law and leaned back.
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: “Nothing wrong, is there?” he asked carelessly, fingering his collar.
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: Beryl’s head was bent; she turned her plate in her fingers.
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: “Nothing,” said her light voice. Then she too looked up, and smiled at
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: Stanley. “Why should there be?”
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: “O-oh! No reason at all as far as I know. I thought you seemed rather—”
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: At that moment the door opened and the three little girls appeared,
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: each carrying a porridge plate. They were dressed alike in blue jerseys
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: and knickers; their brown legs were bare, and each had her hair plaited
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: and pinned up in what was called a horse’s tail. Behind them came Mrs.
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: Fairfield with the tray.
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: “Carefully, children,” she warned. But they were taking the very
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: greatest care. They loved being allowed to carry things. “Have you said
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: good morning to your father?”
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: “Yes, grandma.” They settled themselves on the bench opposite Stanley
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: and Beryl.
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: “Good morning, Stanley!” Old Mrs. Fairfield gave him his plate.
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: “Morning, mother! How’s the boy?”
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: “Splendid! He only woke up once last night. What a perfect morning!”
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: The old woman paused, her hand on the loaf of bread, to gaze out of the
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: open door into the garden. The sea sounded. Through the wide-open
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: window streamed the sun on to the yellow varnished walls and bare
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: floor. Everything on the table flashed and glittered. In the middle
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: there was an old salad bowl filled with yellow and red nasturtiums. She
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: smiled, and a look of deep content shone in her eyes.
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: “You might _cut_ me a slice of that bread, mother,” said Stanley. “I’ve
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: only twelve and a half minutes before the coach passes. Has anyone
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: given my shoes to the servant girl?”
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: “Yes, they’re ready for you.” Mrs. Fairfield was quite unruffled.
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: “Oh, Kezia! Why are you such a messy child!” cried Beryl despairingly.
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: “Me, Aunt Beryl?” Kezia stared at her. What had she done now? She had
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: only dug a river down the middle of her porridge, filled it, and was
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: eating the banks away. But she did that every single morning, and no
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: one had said a word up till now.
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: “Why can’t you eat your food properly like Isabel and Lottie?” How
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: unfair grown-ups are!
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: “But Lottie always makes a floating island, don’t you, Lottie?”
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: “I don’t,” said Isabel smartly. “I just sprinkle mine with sugar and
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: put on the milk and finish it. Only babies play with their food.”
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: Stanley pushed back his chair and got up.
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: “Would you get me those shoes, mother? And, Beryl, if you’ve finished,
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: I wish you’d cut down to the gate and stop the coach. Run in to your
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: mother, Isabel, and ask her where my bowler hat’s been put. Wait a
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: minute—have you children been playing with my stick?”
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: “No, father!”
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: “But I put it here.” Stanley began to bluster. “I remember distinctly
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: putting it in this corner. Now, who’s had it? There’s no time to lose.
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: Look sharp! The stick’s got to be found.”
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: Even Alice, the servant-girl, was drawn into the chase. “You haven’t
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: been using it to poke the kitchen fire with by any chance?”
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: Stanley dashed into the bedroom where Linda was lying. “Most
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: extraordinary thing. I can’t keep a single possession to myself.
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: They’ve made away with my stick, now!”
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: “Stick, dear? What stick?” Linda’s vagueness on these occasions could
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: not be real, Stanley decided. Would nobody sympathize with him?
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: “Coach! Coach, Stanley!” Beryl’s voice cried from the gate.
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: Stanley waved his arm to Linda. “No time to say good-bye!” he cried.
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: And he meant that as a punishment to her.
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: He snatched his bowler hat, dashed out of the house, and swung down the
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: garden path. Yes, the coach was there waiting, and Beryl, leaning over
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: the open gate, was laughing up at somebody or other just as if nothing
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: had happened. The heartlessness of women! The way they took it for
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: granted it was your job to slave away for them while they didn’t even
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: take the trouble to see that your walking-stick wasn’t lost. Kelly
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: trailed his whip across the horses.
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: “Good-bye, Stanley,” called Beryl, sweetly and gaily. It was easy
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: enough to say good-bye! And there she stood, idle, shading her eyes
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: with her hand. The worst of it was Stanley had to shout good-bye too,
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: for the sake of appearances. Then he saw her turn, give a little skip
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: and run back to the house. She was glad to be rid of him!
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: Yes, she was thankful. Into the living-room she ran and called “He’s
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: gone!” Linda cried from her room: “Beryl! Has Stanley gone?” Old Mrs.
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: Fairfield appeared, carrying the boy in his little flannel coatee.
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: “Gone?”
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: “Gone!”
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: Oh, the relief, the difference it made to have the man out of the
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: house. Their very voices were changed as they called to one another;
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: they sounded warm and loving and as if they shared a secret. Beryl went
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: over to the table. “Have another cup of tea, mother. It’s still hot.”
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: She wanted, somehow, to celebrate the fact that they could do what they
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: liked now. There was no man to disturb them; the whole perfect day was
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: theirs.
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: “No, thank you, child,” said old Mrs. Fairfield, but the way at that
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: moment she tossed the boy up and said “a-goos-a-goos-a-ga!” to him
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: meant that she felt the same. The little girls ran into the paddock
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: like chickens let out of a coop.
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: Even Alice, the servant-girl, washing up the dishes in the kitchen,
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: caught the infection and used the precious tank water in a perfectly
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: reckless fashion.
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: “Oh, these men!” said she, and she plunged the teapot into the bowl and
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: held it under the water even after it had stopped bubbling, as if it
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: too was a man and drowning was too good for them.

text: IV
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: “Wait for me, Isa-bel! Kezia, wait for me!”
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: There was poor little Lottie, left behind again, because she found it
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: so fearfully hard to get over the stile by herself. When she stood on
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: the first step her knees began to wobble; she grasped the post. Then
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: you had to put one leg over. But which leg? She never could decide. And
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: when she did finally put one leg over with a sort of stamp of
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: despair—then the feeling was awful. She was half in the paddock still
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: and half in the tussock grass. She clutched the post desperately and
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: lifted up her voice. “Wait for me!”
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: “No, don’t you wait for her, Kezia!” said Isabel. “She’s such a little
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: silly. She’s always making a fuss. Come on!” And she tugged Kezia’s
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: jersey. “You can use my bucket if you come with me,” she said kindly.
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: “It’s bigger than yours.” But Kezia couldn’t leave Lottie all by
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: herself. She ran back to her. By this time Lottie was very red in the
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: face and breathing heavily.
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: “Here, put your other foot over,” said Kezia.
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: “Where?”
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: Lottie looked down at Kezia as if from a mountain height.
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: “Here where my hand is.” Kezia patted the place.
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: “Oh, _there_ do you mean!” Lottie gave a deep sigh and put the second
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: foot over.
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: “Now—sort of turn round and sit down and slide,” said Kezia.
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: “But there’s nothing to sit down _on_, Kezia,” said Lottie.
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: She managed it at last, and once it was over she shook herself and
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: began to beam.
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: “I’m getting better at climbing over stiles, aren’t I, Kezia?”
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: Lottie’s was a very hopeful nature.
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: The pink and the blue sunbonnet followed Isabel’s bright red sunbonnet
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: up that sliding, slipping hill. At the top they paused to decide where
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: to go and to have a good stare at who was there already. Seen from
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: behind, standing against the skyline, gesticulating largely with their
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: spades, they looked like minute puzzled explorers.
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: The whole family of Samuel Josephs was there already with their
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: lady-help, who sat on a camp-stool and kept order with a whistle that
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: she wore tied round her neck, and a small cane with which she directed
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: operations. The Samuel Josephs never played by themselves or managed
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: their own game. If they did, it ended in the boys pouring water down
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: the girls’ necks or the girls trying to put little black crabs into the
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: boys’ pockets. So Mrs. S. J. and the poor lady-help drew up what she
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: called a “brogramme” every morning to keep them “abused and out of
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: bischief.” It was all competitions or races or round games. Everything
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: began with a piercing blast of the lady-help’s whistle and ended with
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: another. There were even prizes—large, rather dirty paper parcels which
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: the lady-help with a sour little smile drew out of a bulging string
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: kit. The Samuel Josephs fought fearfully for the prizes and cheated and
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: pinched one another’s arms—they were all expert pinchers. The only time
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: the Burnell children ever played with them Kezia had got a prize, and
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: when she undid three bits of paper she found a very small rusty
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: button-hook. She couldn’t understand why they made such a fuss....
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: But they never played with the Samuel Josephs now or even went to their
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: parties. The Samuel Josephs were always giving children’s parties at
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: There was not an inch of room for Lottie and Kezia in the buggy. When
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: Pat swung them on top of the luggage they wobbled; the grandmother’s
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: lap was full and Linda Burnell could not possibly have held a lump of a
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: child on hers for any distance. Isabel, very superior, was perched
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: beside the new handy-man on the driver’s seat. Hold-alls, bags and
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: boxes were piled upon the floor. “These are absolute necessities that I
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: will not let out of my sight for one instant,” said Linda Burnell, her
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: voice trembling with fatigue and excitement.
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: Lottie and Kezia stood on the patch of lawn just inside the gate all
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: ready for the fray in their coats with brass anchor buttons and little
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: round caps with battleship ribbons. Hand in hand, they stared with
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: round solemn eyes first at the absolute necessities and then at their
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: mother.
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: “We shall simply have to leave them. That is all. We shall simply have
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: to cast them off,” said Linda Burnell. A strange little laugh flew from
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: her lips; she leaned back against the buttoned leather cushions and
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: shut her eyes, her lips trembling with laughter. Happily at that moment
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: Mrs. Samuel Josephs, who had been watching the scene from behind her
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: drawing-room blind, waddled down the garden path.
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: “Why nod leave the chudren with be for the afterdoon, Brs. Burnell?
author: Katherine Mansfield

author: Katherine Mansfield

text: eveding. Those thigs on the path have to go, dod’t they?”
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: “Yes, everything outside the house is supposed to go,” said Linda
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: Burnell, and she waved a white hand at the tables and chairs standing
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: on their heads on the front lawn. How absurd they looked! Either they
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: ought to be the other way up, or Lottie and Kezia ought to stand on
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: their heads, too. And she longed to say: “Stand on your heads,
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: children, and wait for the store-man.” It seemed to her that would be
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: so exquisitely funny that she could not attend to Mrs. Samuel Josephs.
author: Katherine Mansfield

author: Katherine Mansfield

text: face smiled. “Dod’t you worry, Brs. Burnell. Loddie and Kezia can have
author: Katherine Mansfield

author: Katherine Mansfield

text: afterwards.”
author: Katherine Mansfield

author: Katherine Mansfield

author: Katherine Mansfield

author: Katherine Mansfield

author: Katherine Mansfield

author: Katherine Mansfield

author: Katherine Mansfield

author: Katherine Mansfield

author: Katherine Mansfield

author: Katherine Mansfield

author: Katherine Mansfield

author: Katherine Mansfield

author: Katherine Mansfield

author: Katherine Mansfield

author: Katherine Mansfield

author: Katherine Mansfield

author: Katherine Mansfield

author: Katherine Mansfield

author: Katherine Mansfield

author: Katherine Mansfield

author: Katherine Mansfield

author: Katherine Mansfield

text: them.

author: Katherine Mansfield

author: Katherine Mansfield

author: Katherine Mansfield

author: Katherine Mansfield

author: Katherine Mansfield

author: Katherine Mansfield

author: Katherine Mansfield

author: Katherine Mansfield

author: Katherine Mansfield

text: “I could keep a bird’s egg in that,” she decided.
author: Katherine Mansfield

author: Katherine Mansfield

author: Katherine Mansfield

author: Katherine Mansfield

author: Katherine Mansfield

author: Katherine Mansfield

author: Katherine Mansfield

author: Katherine Mansfield

author: Katherine Mansfield

author: Katherine Mansfield

author: Katherine Mansfield

author: Katherine Mansfield

author: Katherine Mansfield

author: Katherine Mansfield

author: Katherine Mansfield

author: Katherine Mansfield

author: Katherine Mansfield

author: Katherine Mansfield

author: Katherine Mansfield

author: Katherine Mansfield

author: Katherine Mansfield

author: Katherine Mansfield

text: The Escape
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: It was his fault, wholly and solely his fault, that they had missed the
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: train. What if the idiotic hotel people had refused to produce the
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: bill? Wasn’t that simply because he hadn’t impressed upon the waiter at
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: lunch that they must have it by two o’clock? Any other man would have
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: sat there and refused to move until they handed it over. But no! His
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: exquisite belief in human nature had allowed him to get up and expect
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: one of those idiots to bring it to their room. . . . And then, when the
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: _voiture_ did arrive, while they were still (Oh, Heavens!) waiting for
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: change, why hadn’t he seen to the arrangement of the boxes so that they
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: could, at least, have started the moment the money had come? Had he
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: expected her to go outside, to stand under the awning in the heat and
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: point with her parasol? Very amusing picture of English domestic life.
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: Even when the driver had been told how fast he had to drive he had paid
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: no attention whatsoever—just smiled. “Oh,” she groaned, “if she’d been
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: a driver she couldn’t have stopped smiling herself at the absurd,
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: ridiculous way he was urged to hurry.” And she sat back and imitated
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: his voice: “_Allez, vite, vite_”—and begged the driver’s pardon for
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: troubling him. . . .
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: And then the station—unforgettable—with the sight of the jaunty little
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: train shuffling away and those hideous children waving from the
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: windows. “Oh, why am I made to bear these things? Why am I exposed to
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: them? . . .” The glare, the flies, while they waited, and he and the
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: stationmaster put their heads together over the time-table, trying to
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: find this other train, which, of course, they wouldn’t catch. The
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: people who’d gathered round, and the woman who’d held up that baby with
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: that awful, awful head. . . . “Oh, to care as I care—to feel as I feel,
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: and never to be saved anything—never to know for one moment what it was
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: Her voice had changed. It was shaking now—crying now. She fumbled with
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: her bag, and produced from its little maw a scented handkerchief. She
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: put up her veil and, as though she were doing it for somebody else,
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: pitifully, as though she were saying to somebody else: “I know, my
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: darling,” she pressed the handkerchief to her eyes.
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: The little bag, with its shiny, silvery jaws open, lay on her lap. He
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: could see her powder-puff, her rouge stick, a bundle of letters, a
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: phial of tiny black pills like seeds, a broken cigarette, a mirror,
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: white ivory tablets with lists on them that had been heavily scored
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: through. He thought: “In Egypt she would be buried with those things.”
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: They had left the last of the houses, those small straggling houses
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: with bits of broken pot flung among the flower-beds and half-naked hens
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: scratching round the doorsteps. Now they were mounting a long steep
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: road that wound round the hill and over into the next bay. The horses
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: stumbled, pulling hard. Every five minutes, every two minutes the
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: driver trailed the whip across them. His stout back was solid as wood;
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: there were boils on his reddish neck, and he wore a new, a shining new
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: straw hat. . . .
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: There was a little wind, just enough wind to blow to satin the new
author: Katherine Mansfield

author: Katherine Mansfield

text: the smoky olives—just enough wind to start in front of the carriage a
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: whirling, twirling snatch of dust that settled on their clothes like
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: the finest ash. When she took out her powder-puff the powder came
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: flying over them both.
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: “Oh, the dust,” she breathed, “the disgusting, revolting dust.” And she
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: put down her veil and lay back as if overcome.
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: “Why don’t you put up your parasol?” he suggested. It was on the front
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: seat, and he leaned forward to hand it to her. At that she suddenly sat
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: upright and blazed again.
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: “Please leave my parasol alone! I don’t want my parasol! And anyone who
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: was not utterly insensitive would know that I’m far, far too exhausted
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: to hold up a parasol. And with a wind like this tugging at it. . . .
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: Put it down at once,” she flashed, and then snatched the parasol from
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: him, tossed it into the crumpled hood behind, and subsided, panting.
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: Another bend of the road, and down the hill there came a troop of
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: little children, shrieking and giggling, little girls with sun-bleached
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: hair, little boys in faded soldiers’ caps. In their hands they carried
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: flowers—any kind of flowers—grabbed by the head, and these they
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: offered, running beside the carriage. Lilac, faded lilac, greeny-white
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: snowballs, one arum lily, a handful of hyacinths. They thrust the
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: flowers and their impish faces into the carriage; one even threw into
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: her lap a bunch of marigolds. Poor little mice! He had his hand in his
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: trouser pocket before her. “For Heaven’s sake don’t give them anything.
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: Oh, how typical of you! Horrid little monkeys! Now they’ll follow us
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: all the way. Don’t encourage them; you _would_ encourage beggars”; and
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: she hurled the bunch out of the carriage with, “Well, do it when I’m
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: not there, please.”
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: He saw the queer shock on the children’s faces. They stopped running,
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: lagged behind, and then they began to shout something, and went on
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: shouting until the carriage had rounded yet another bend.
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: “Oh, how many more are there before the top of the hill is reached? The
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: horses haven’t trotted once. Surely it isn’t necessary for them to walk
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: the whole way.”
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: “We shall be there in a minute now,” he said, and took out his
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: cigarette-case. At that she turned round towards him. She clasped her
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: hands and held them against her breast; her dark eyes looked immense,
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: imploring, behind her veil; her nostrils quivered, she bit her lip, and
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: her head shook with a little nervous spasm. But when she spoke, her
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: voice was quite weak and very, very calm.
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: “I want to ask you something. I want to beg something of you,” she
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: said. “I’ve asked you hundreds and hundreds of times before, but you’ve
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: forgotten. It’s such a little thing, but if you knew what it meant to
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: me. . . .” She pressed her hands together. “But you can’t know. No
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: human creature could know and be so cruel.” And then, slowly,
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: deliberately, gazing at him with those huge, sombre eyes: “I beg and
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: implore you for the last time that when we are driving together you
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: won’t smoke. If you could imagine,” she said, “the anguish I suffer
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: when that smoke comes floating across my face. . . .”
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: “Very well,” he said. “I won’t. I forgot.” And he put the case back.
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: “Oh, no,” said she, and almost began to laugh, and put the back of her
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: hand across her eyes. “You couldn’t have forgotten. Not that.”
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: The wind came, blowing stronger. They were at the top of the hill.
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: “Hoy-yip-yip-yip,” cried the driver. They swung down the road that fell
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: into a small valley, skirted the sea coast at the bottom of it, and
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: then coiled over a gentle ridge on the other side. Now there were
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: houses again, blue-shuttered against the heat, with bright burning
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: gardens, with geranium carpets flung over the pinkish walls. The
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: coast-line was dark; on the edge of the sea a white silky fringe just
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: stirred. The carriage swung down the hill, bumped, shook. “Yi-ip,”
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: shouted the driver. She clutched the sides of the seat, she closed her
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: eyes, and he knew she felt this was happening on purpose; this swinging
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: and bumping, this was all done—and he was responsible for it,
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: somehow—to spite her because she had asked if they couldn’t go a little
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: faster. But just as they reached the bottom of the valley there was one
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: tremendous lurch. The carriage nearly overturned, and he saw her eyes
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: blaze at him, and she positively hissed, “I suppose you are enjoying
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: this?”

author: Katherine Mansfield

text: up. “_Cocher! Cocher! Arrêtez-vous!_” She turned round and looked into
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: the crumpled hood behind. “I knew it,” she exclaimed. “I knew it. I
author: Katherine Mansfield

author: Katherine Mansfield

text: “What? Where?”
author: Katherine Mansfield

author: Katherine Mansfield

author: Katherine Mansfield

author: Katherine Mansfield

text: “I, too, heard something,” said he, simply and gaily. “But I thought as
author: Katherine Mansfield

author: Katherine Mansfield

author: Katherine Mansfield

text: accounts for the extraordinary smile on your face. . . .”
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: “Look here,” he said, “it can’t be gone. If it fell out it will be
author: Katherine Mansfield

author: Katherine Mansfield

text: But she saw through that. Oh, how she saw through it! “No, thank you.”

author: Katherine Mansfield

author: Katherine Mansfield

author: Katherine Mansfield

author: Katherine Mansfield

author: Katherine Mansfield

author: Katherine Mansfield

author: Katherine Mansfield

author: Katherine Mansfield

author: Katherine Mansfield

author: Katherine Mansfield

author: Katherine Mansfield

author: Katherine Mansfield

text: looked at the tree he felt his breathing die away and he became part of
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: the silence. It seemed to grow, it seemed to expand in the quivering
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: heat until the great carved leaves hid the sky, and yet it was
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: motionless. Then from within its depths or from beyond there came the
author: Katherine Mansfield

author: Katherine Mansfield

author: Katherine Mansfield

text: was part of it. Suddenly, as the voice rose, soft, dreaming, gentle, he
author: Katherine Mansfield

text: knew that it would come floating to him from the hidden leaves and his
author: Katherine Mansfield

author: Katherine Mansfield

author: Katherine Mansfield

author: Katherine Mansfield

author: Katherine Mansfield

author: Katherine Mansfield

author: Katherine Mansfield

author: Katherine Mansfield

author: Katherine Mansfield

author: Katherine Mansfield
